awd_titl_txt: Physical principles of magnetic extraction from microfluidic droplets
awd_abstract_narration:
New treatments for disease are enabled by technological advances that create, isolate, characterize, and test novel therapeutic agents and cellular reagents. To accelerate testing of millions of candidate therapeutics, researchers have miniaturized typical laboratory techniques onto small chips called microfluidic devices.  Microfluidics control and handle extremely small volumes of fluids in networks of micron-size conduits. A sample of interest is immersed in a tiny droplet of highly stable carrier oil to be precisely controlled through the conduits at high speed. This approach has enabled millions of parallel tests to study treatments for cancer, autoimmune disorders, and many other diseases. However, recovery of the sample of interest from the oil is difficult, and is often essential for additional analysis or processing. To enable this technology, this project will use tiny magnets to extract the samples of interest from the oil carrier droplets, and elucidate the fundamental physics that govern the behavior of droplets in a magnetic field. 

This project will extract and capture molecules from droplets using functionalized magnetic beads. The beads will be concentrated into a corner of the droplet with an external magnetic field.  Then, the droplet will be split to concentrate the beads into a smaller, daughter droplet. This project will provide a fundamental understanding of the complex hydrodynamic, magnetic, and capillary forces in this extraction process.  The coupling between hydrodynamic and magnetic forces in flowing droplets will be correlated to bead dispersion. The capillary number will be related to non-parallel droplet splitting.  The developed theory will be validated by magnetic extraction of messenger ribonucleic acid (RNA) from cell lysates, followed by quantification. This project will use microfluidics as a teaching tool to demonstrate physics fundamentals and engineering design, with outreach to underrepresented minority students and educators who drive statewide curriculum.

por.por_cntn:
Our project sought to study the extraction of magnetic beads from tiny aqueous droplets to increase the capabilities of droplet microfluidics. In droplet microfluidics, samples are encapsulated in droplets of very small volume (picoliter to nanoliter). These droplets can be manipulated at very high-throughput, thousands per second, to process the sample using a series of modules. Most operations that can be performed at the macro-scale can be performed at the microfluidic droplet level, except for the very critical step of purification. Purification from droplets is challenging due to their resilience. In this project, our goal was to improve upon a strategy we developed to purify components from microfluidic droplets and to develop a basic understanding of the phenomena at play in that purification.

Purification is instrumental in all analytical and preparative methods for biology and chemistry. Our project is extending this modality to droplet microfluidics. As a result, numerous assays will benefit from the high-throughput and scale reduction in reagent usage enabled by droplet microfluidics. Hence, the impact will be far beyond the basic knowledge of the fundamental physical mechanisms at play in the system.

Specifically, one aspect of our project focused on describing the behavior of assemblies of magnetic beads under hydrodynamic conditions that tend to disperse them. We investigated the opposing effects of magnetic and viscous forces that drive and disrupt bead aggregation. Until now, those effects have been described in a very specific system where a rotating magnetic field influences bead aggregates. Here, we expand the study to a different experimental model, i.e., microfluidic droplets and a wide range of geometrical parameters. The result of our project has been unearthing a more general behavior of the magneto-viscous system. It will expand the definition of the dimensionless Mason number that describes the relative effect of magnetic and viscous forces.

In addition, we have developed and generalized a new method to measure hydrodynamic flows in three dimensions. Current techniques require an elaborate optical set-up and provide only information within slices or planes without information between those. Our results demonstrate that we can generate a 3D map of experimental microflows at micron-scale resolution using a widely accessible brightfield microscope without a specialized set-up or high-end objective. Additionally, we show that cross-correlation and deep learning approaches perform equally well for determining the Z-position of seed particles from experimental data. We validated our method on two highly relevant microfluidic examples. First, our data highlight the flow structure induced by displacement structures and elucidate how it efficiently shifts large particles across streamlines. Second, our high-resolution 3D flow maps of microfluidic droplets revealed novel recirculation structures and folding patterns that could not be previously observed with typical flow mapping techniques like PIV. These examples demonstrated the capabilities of our method to generate true 3D flow maps at high spatial and temporal resolution. Our method will support the design and development of novel microfluidic structures to address the growing demand for manipulating samples at the micron-scale

Finally, the project provided us with an opportunity to develop an outreach module for K-12 science education. We developed a simple module that requires only easily available materials such as a water bottle, a straw, a funnel, and timers. This simple module aims to stress the power of observation and tease young students? curiosity and inquisitiveness with fun and counter-intuitive experiments. At the same time, the module introduces the rigorous concepts of scientific inquiry: observation, hypothesis, testing, statistics, and critical notions such as measurement and statistics. Our outreach module will hopefully attract the attention and the interest of K-12 students towards STEM disciplines.

Overall, the project has provided us with new opportunities to perform research in basic hydrodynamics phenomena when the laboratory focused on developing applications. Beyond learning the basics of data analysis using Python, students involved in the project also had the opportunity to train in microscopy, electronics, and engineering to expand our experimental capabilities and test new hypotheses. Altogether, the project supported the training of a post-doc, 3 Ph.D. students, five undergraduate students, and one high-school student.

The first outcome of this project consists of a simple and widely available method to analyze flows in 3D at micron-scale. The second outcome of this project is the knowledge gained on the interplay between hydrodynamic and magnetic forces. This knowledge will allow us to design more efficient purification methods. This will directly impact the ability to improve diagnostics and improve human health by providing physicians with actionable information. We anticipate that the newly acquired knowledge will enable us to study biomedical phenomena such as platelet activation and develop new label-free detection modalities. The third outcome of the project is the development of an outreach module for K-12 science education. Finally, the fourth outcome of the project has been the training of future leaders in the biomedical engineering field.
